revision.text:
{|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=[[File:Spreewald 26.jpg|300px]] |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country= |Ship flag={{shipboxflag|German Empire}} {{shipboxflag|Nazi Germany}} |Ship name=''Spreewald'' |Ship namesake=[[Spreewald]] |Ship owner= |Ship operator=[[Hamburg America Line]] |Ship registry= |Ship route= |Ship ordered= |Ship awarded= |Ship builder=[[Deutsche Werft]], [[Hamburg]] |Ship original cost= |Ship yard number= |Ship way number= |Ship laid down= |Ship launched=1922 |Ship sponsor= |Ship christened= |Ship completed= |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= |Ship decommissioned= |Ship maiden voyage= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship renamed=*''Anubis'', 1935 *''Spreewald'', 1939 |Ship reclassified= |Ship refit= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship homeport=[[Hamburg]] |Ship identification= |Ship motto= |Ship nickname= |Ship fate=Sunk, 31 January 1942 |Ship notes= |Ship badge= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= |Ship type=[[Merchant vessel]] |Ship tonnage={{GRT|5,083|disp=long}} |Ship displacement= |Ship length= |Ship beam= |Ship height= |Ship draught= |Ship depth= |Ship hold depth= |Ship decks= |Ship deck clearance= |Ship power= |Ship propulsion= |Ship speed= |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship capacity= |Ship crew= |Ship sensors= |Ship armament=None |Ship notes= }} |} '''''Spreewald''''' was a German passenger-carrying freighter built in 1922 by [[Deutsche Werft]] at [[Hamburg]] for the [[Hamburg America Line]]. The ship was renamed ''Anubis'' in 1935, but reverted to ''Spreewald'' in 1939. On 31 January 1942 when returning to Germany in disguise, she was sunk by {{Ship|German submarine|U-333||2}}.<ref name="uboat.net">{{Cite web |url= http://www.uboat.net/allies/merchants/ships/1305.html |first=Guðmundur |last=Helgason |title=''Spreewald'' |work=uboat.net |accessdate=12 April 2010 }}</ref>
==Service history== ''Spreewald'' ran aground at [[Emden]], [[Lower Saxony]], Germany, on 28 April 1924.<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Casualty reports |day_of_week=Thursday |date=29 May 1924 |page_number=27 |issue=43664 |column=G }}</ref> She was refloated the next day.<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Casualty reports |day_of_week=Thursday |date=1 May 1924 |page_number=22 |issue=43640 |column=E }}</ref>
At the outbreak of World War II, the ship was interned at [[Lüshunkou District|Port Arthur]], [[China]].<ref name="gduncan">{{Cite web |url= http://members.iinet.net.au/~gduncan/maritime-2-1942.html |title=More Maritime Disasters of WWII - 1942 - ''Spreewald'' |first=George |last=Duncan |work=members.iinet.net.au |accessdate=12 April 2010 }}</ref> In 1941 she was brought back into service and sailed on 21 October 1941,<ref name="gduncan"/> loaded with 3,365 tons of [[rubber]], 230 tons of [[tin]] and 20 tons of [[tungsten]], and [[quinine]].<ref name="uboat.net"/> While en route to Germany she rendezvoused with the German supply ship ''[[Kulmerland (ship)|Kulmerland]]'' and embarked 86 British prisoners,<ref name="uboat.net"/> survivors of ships sunk by the [[auxiliary cruiser]] ''[[German auxiliary cruiser Kormoran|Kormoran]]''.<ref name="gduncan"/>
On 31 January 1942 ''Spreewald'' was on her approach to [[Bordeaux]] in France when she was torpedoed by ''U-333'', whose commander, ''Kapitänleutnant'' [[Peter-Erich Cremer]], believed her to be a British ship. ''U-333'' fired two torpedoes, which hit ''Spreewald'' amidships, causing her to burn furiously and slowly sink<ref name="gduncan"/> in position {{coord|45|12|N|24|50|W|dim:2000000|display=inline,title}}<ref name="uboat.net"/>
A search for survivors was promptly launched in which ''U-333'', {{Ship|German submarine|U-575||2}}, and {{Ship|German submarine|U-123|1940|2}}, were joined by {{Ship|German submarine|U-701||2}}, {{Ship|German submarine|U-582||2}}, {{Ship|German submarine|U-332||2}}, and {{Ship|German submarine|U-105|1940|2}}, as well as five ''[[Luftwaffe]]'' [[Focke-Wulf Fw 200|Fw 200 Kondor]] long-range patrol aircraft from bases in [[France]].<ref name="uboat.net"/>
''U-105'' picked up 25 crewmen and 55 prisoners in lifeboats and rafts. Of the 152 aboard the ''Spreewald'', 72 were killed.<ref name="uboat.net"/>
Cremer was subsequently [[court-martial]]led, but found not guilty.<ref name="uboat.net"/>
==References== ;Notes {{Reflist}} ;Bibliography * [http://www.uboat.net/allies/merchants/ships/1305.html ''Spreewald'' - Ships hit by U-boats - uboat.net] * [http://members.iinet.net.au/~gduncan/maritime-2-1942.html More Maritime Disasters of WWII 1942]
